comments:
The class ProcessBuilder (available from JDK 1.5) is used to set up a process 
before starting it (its command, working directory, and environment 
variables).  It takes two different constructors.  The bug is that Eclipse 3.1 
recognizes the class constructors 
(http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/ProcessBuilder.html).  
Consider this code:


      public static void main(String[] args) throws java.io.IOException
      {
            ProcessBuilder pb = new ProcessBuilder("notepad");
            Process p = pb.start(); 
      }

When compiled using the JDK it compiles and executes fine ? launches Notepad

When compiled using Eclipse 3.1 it fails to compile:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Error: Unresolved compilation problem: 
The constructor ProcessBuilder(String) is undefined
  at ProcessBuilderEclipse.main(ProcessBuilderEclipse.java:9)

The weird thing is that the class is recognized but none of its constructors 
are.  This compiles and executes:

public static void main(String[] args) throws java.io.IOException
{
    ProcessBuilder pb = null; 
    System.out.println("finished test");
}

 
Eclipse?s configuration (attached) states is using JDK 1.5

You need to set up your project to use the compliance 1.5. You are compiling in
compliance 1.4. The ProcessBuilder constructor has a variable argument and this
works only in 1.5.
Go to your project properties:
Check "Enable project specific settings"
Then select the compiler compliance level to 1.5. And click apply.
It will recompile the project and it should work.
I tried your test case and it worked fine.
Closing as WORKSFORME. Reopen if you get other issues once you have the right
settings.
